jsa@... wrote:

> The reason I write all this down is that I'd like to hear wether anyone of
> you has any experience/good advice for this kind of unit-test-free legacy
> system. I'd be interested how you use functionality tests (in addition to
> unit tests?) and wether anyone knows any tools that are better suited for
> this kind of job than JUnit.

Well, Michael Feathers has written a fair amount about testing legacy 
code (code without tests). You might like to hunt down what he writes 
about that.

My codebase rescue approach these days is two-pronged:

1. Work with the people who know what the system is supposed to do, then 
write acceptance tests that capture that knowledge. I often do this with 
Fit/FitNesse.

2. Write only the object tests I need to enable the refactoring 
/required/ by fixing a defect or adding a feature. It would be nice to 
refactor for its own sake, but I can't prove that that delivers value. I 
/can/ prove that refactoring for 30 minutes saved me an hour adding a 
feature, so it was worth doing.

As for tools, I do heavily data-driven testing as well as acceptance 
testing with Fit, and I do object-level behavior testing with JUnit. If 
you don't know Fit, and JUnit is working for you, then keep using JUnit 
until you have a spare moment to experiment with Fit. :)
